channel.title: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13

item.title: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13
item.dc:creator: @Revitalize Revitalize
item.description:
@Revitalize wrote:

[quote=“Taharok, post:44, topic:525956”]Vain_ beat me to it, but the best I’ve used yet for designing GUI applications is the Window Builder add-on to Eclipse. It’s ridiculously easy to use, it actually parses your code so you can change the code directly and it won’t break the visual forms, it hasn’t messed up for me yet in my hundreds of hours of using it, and it works very effectively for the entire Swing package. I’m not sure if I have ever been more pleased about any other piece of software than I am with this one.

I would also recommend you to never program GUIs by hand if you have an option to use an editor. There’s only so much you can do without visualizing it, not to mention there are things designed in Swing specifically for WYSIWYG editors, such as GroupLayout which is really complex to code with by hand, but is very simple to use with a builder. Mind you, I’ve found that almost every problem in GUI design can be solved with a GroupLayout. There are a few cases of misalignment that are easier solved with some grid-based layouts.

Hope that helps.[/quote]

Yeah, I actually am using NetBeans for the GUI and designing of this application now, (was using Np++). I’m seriously trying to get into the business of programming/software design. I also like to create video games on the side. x)

Read full topic
item.source: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13

item.title: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13
item.dc:creator: @mod_taharok Taharok
item.description:
@mod_taharok wrote:

Vain_ beat me to it, but the best I’ve used yet for designing GUI applications is the Window Builder add-on to Eclipse. It’s ridiculously easy to use, it actually parses your code so you can change the code directly and it won’t break the visual forms, it hasn’t messed up for me yet in my hundreds of hours of using it, and it works very effectively for the entire Swing package. I’m not sure if I have ever been more pleased about any other piece of software than I am with this one.

I would also recommend you to never program GUIs by hand if you have an option to use an editor. There’s only so much you can do without visualizing it, not to mention there are things designed in Swing specifically for WYSIWYG editors, such as GroupLayout which is really complex to code with by hand, but is very simple to use with a builder. Mind you, I’ve found that almost every problem in GUI design can be solved with a GroupLayout. There are a few cases of misalignment that are easier solved with some grid-based layouts.

Hope that helps.

Read full topic

item.source: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13

item.title: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

[quote=“xx matty xx, post:30, topic:525956”][quote author=Tutorial link=topic=644700.msg4338626#msg4338626 date=1374778664]

So java pros… what’s the right way to do a GUI in Java? Because every swing GUI I’ve ever seen has been absolutely disgusting, and the code is always much worse.

I’ve actually been working on a simple GUI-based application, and I could create a thread and post the source code there if you would like.
[/quote]
Well I know swing and can keep the code fairly clean, but as a web developer constructing Java GUIs seems so convoluted. HTML and CSS give you so much more power, and yet they weren’t even originally designed for producing complex GUIs. Surely a toolkit must exist for Java, short of just using a WYSIWYG editor in an IDE.[/quote]
Some IDEs have support for using a palette to create objects with Swing, but I wouldn’t recommend doing this unless you are using it for easy positioning, because GUI really isn’t too complex once you get a better understanding of the Swing API. As for other programs (toolkits) that allow you to easily create GUI-based applications, the only one I’ve seen is TWL (Themable Widget Library), which is rather like an add-on to Swing to give your GUI a better and more themed look.

Read full topic

item.title: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13
item.dc:creator: @Revitalize Revitalize
item.description:
@Revitalize wrote:

[quote=“Vain_, post:38, topic:525956”][quote author=Revitalize link=topic=644700.msg4338825#msg4338825 date=1374804989]

you’re welcome. and good luck with this.

could be a userful data storage device. but i wouldn’t recommend flatfile writing just with bufferedwriter. try storing the data efficiently, perhaps binary or maybe a database.

I want to use XML or SQL. You know? This is just SUPER basic. I want to network in my future for a living. No idea where to start, but here I am. Trying to learn all I can in basic java before I move on x)
[/quote]by network you mean? (database manager etc?)

the concept you have is not bad. however, you should attempt to create a basic login system (use login for the author, instead of prompting for it on the gui). rename the author field to published by (this way, other users can ‘publish’ the book to your library database, without claiming themselves as the author.

try changing genre field to a jcomboxbox (dropdown) so users cannot create random genres.

add a viewport of some sort (field tree, list, etc) for all books genres, books by author, etc[/quote]

Wow, never thought of that. And yeah, I plan on adding another tab so you can search the database, etc. Do you have skype?

Read full topic

could be a userful data storage device. but i wouldn’t recommend flatfile writing just with bufferedwriter. try storing the data efficiently, perhaps binary or maybe a database.
[/quote]

I want to use XML or SQL. You know? This is just SUPER basic. I want to network in my future for a living. No idea where to start, but here I am. Trying to learn all I can in basic java before I move on x)[/quote]by network you mean? (database manager etc?)

the concept you have is not bad. however, you should attempt to create a basic login system (use login for the author, instead of prompting for it on the gui). rename the author field to published by (this way, other users can ‘publish’ the book to your library database, without claiming themselves as the author.

try changing genre field to a jcomboxbox (dropdown) so users cannot create random genres.

add a viewport of some sort (field tree, list, etc) for all books genres, books by author, etc

towards op: add a check towards the book ids? what happens if you make a book, and accidentally overwrite it with a blank one! simply check the ids, and ask for confirmation to overwrite, or simply give the old book a new id, and save the new book as the specified id

I will! I can do that pretty easily, i would assume. By the way, nice, thanks for that program. It looks amazing lol.

item.title: Library program in the making? Picture added *prettier* updated 7/29/13
item.dc:creator: @Tutorial Tutorial
item.description:
@Tutorial wrote:

xx matty xx:

So java pros… what’s the right way to do a GUI in Java? Because every swing GUI I’ve ever seen has been absolutely disgusting, and the code is always much worse.

I’ve actually been working on a simple GUI-based application, and I could create a thread and post the source code there if you would like.

Revitalize:

Well, I was using absolute positioning (no layout), Honestly, I SHOULD be using an IDE to help me make this. But I wanna code from scratch because I wanna learn for later reference. You know?

There is nothing wrong with absolute positioning, because not all of the layouts that Swing provides will completely match the setup for your GUI.
